IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: BETHANY LUTHERAN COLLEGE IS A PRIVATE, RESIDENTIAL, LIBERAL ARTS COLLEGE COMMITTED TO THE TEACHINGS OF THE BIBLE AS SET FORTH IN THE LUTHERAN CONFESSIONS. BETHANY PROVIDES STUDIES CULMINATING IN A BACHELOR OF ARTS DEGREE. BETHANY LUTHERAN THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY EXISTS IN ORDER TO TRAIN MEN FOR THE PUBLIC MINISTRY IN THE ELS AS WELL AS TO SERVE THE SYNOD'S THEOLOGICAL NEEDS.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Bethany Lutheran College, owned and operated by the Evangelical Lutheran Synod, is a private, residential, liberal arts college committed to the teachings of the Bible as set forth in the Lutheran Confessions. Bethany provides studies culminating in a Bachelor of Arts degree. The College serves Lutherans and others by offering a challenging, student-centered approach to education that fosters spiritual development, intellectual and creative growth, self-understanding, and responsible citizenship. In keeping with its heritage, Bethany aspires to produce students with a clear understanding of Christian vocation, which encourages students to make the most of their God-given talents.
IRS990.Description: Instruction: Bethany Lutheran College awards the Bachelor of Arts degrees with majors in more than 19 subject areas and a Master of Divinity and a Master of Arts degrees. The 2009-2010 academic year enrollment was 645 full time equivalent (FTE) students in the Fall Semester and 595 FTE students enrolled in the Spring Semester. Of the total number of students enrolled in 2009-2010 academic year, 146 met the requirements of graduation.

Activity2.Description: Student Services & Academic Support: Bethany boasts a long-standing commitment to educating the whole person by nourishing the intellectual, spiritual, emotional, social and physical dimensions of students' lives. The College offers a curriculum that challenges students to think critically and express themselves effectively, a campus life that encourages involvement and service (over 20 student organizations), a community of faith that nutures spiritual growth and develops moral responsibility, and co-curricular activities that inspire students to test their own limits and express their individuality.

Activity3.Description: Auxiliary enterprises at Bethany Lutheran College provides 5 residence halls on campus, 2 dining venues, and a bookstore for students, faculty and staff. Of the total student body, 70% of enrolled students lived on-campus and participated in the resident student board plan. 444 students resided in campus housing in the 2009-2010 Fall Semester and 418 in the Spring Semester.

ActivityOther.Description: Other Program Services include operations and maintenance of plant and institutional support. These programs provide services to operate and maintain buildings and grounds and to support instiutional operations other than management and general.

OtherLiabilities.Description: Deposits Held in Custody for Others

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Bethany Lutheran College's endowment funds are used to fund scholarships to students, the general operations of the college, and other special projects such as faculty development, departmental needs and library needs.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.ReturnReference: Description of Uncertain Tax Positions Under FIN 48:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Internal Revenue Service has determined that the Corporation is exempt from federal income tax under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. It is also exempt from state income tax. However, any unrelated business income may be subject to taxation. In accordance with the accounting standard on Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes, the Corporation addresses the determination of whether tax benefits claimed on a tax return should be recorded in the financial statements. Under this guidance, the Corporation may recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained on examination by taxing authorities, based on the technical merit of the position. Examples of tax positions include the tax-exempt status of the Corporation and various positions related to the potential sources of unrelated business taxable income. There were no significant unrecognized tax benefits identified or recorded as liabilities during fiscal year 2010. Open tax years subject to examination by the U.S. and state taxing authorities are for the years 2007 to 2009, which statutes expire in 2011 to 2013, respectively.
Fundraising Event Expenses: -29472. Scholarships and grants: 5098650.

IRS990ScheduleE.PubViaBroadcastMediaExpln: The use of these media formats are primarily used for event related activities. The College does not use them to solicit students for enrollment.
IRS990ScheduleE.GovtFinancialAidExplanation: BETHANY LUTHERAN COLLEGE PARTICIPATES IN TITLE IV FINANCIAL AID PROGRAMS, SO MANY STUDENTS RECEIVE AID THROUGH FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES.

Form990ScheduleIPartIII.TypeOfGrant: Scholarships and Grants provided as financial aid to students - see College for detailed list

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: Bethany Lutheran College offers scholarships and grants to qualified students to help reduce their out-of-pocket tuition costs. Students receiving financial assistance of this form must meet specific criteria such as academic achievement, financial need, and other similar standards whether put in place by the College or by donors of restricted funds.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: John Moldstad, President of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod has a family relationship with the College President, Dan Bruss, and the College Chaplain Don Moldstad.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 7a
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The ELS delegates have the authority or right to elect members of the governing body.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The 990 is reviewed by the Finance and Audit Committee at their February meeting each year.After the Form 990 is reviewed by the Finance and Audit Committee a full copy of the 990 is provided to the Board of Regents for review prior to the filing of the Form 990.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Annually the full Board of Regents is asked to read and sign the Conflict of Interest Policy. If a conflict is determined to exsist the board memeber invovled would abstain from voting on the conflict.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Daniel Mundahl, CFAO, gathers information from CUPA, The Chronicle of Higher Education and from MPCC (MN Private College Council) for comparisons using the medium measure and looking at colleges of similar size and purpose. This information is provided to the executive committee who reviews, evaluates, and determines compensation for the President, officers and other individuals.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All policies that are available for public viewing would be made available upon request.
THE COLLEGE HAS NOT CHANGED ITS OVERSIGHT PROCESS OR SELECTION PROCESS HAS NOT CHANGED DURING THE YEAR.
